question.title: Why does ScheduledExecutorService.shutdown() uses 100% of my CPU?

node.contents: Can you take a thread dump while the cpu is pegged at 100%?

astNode.text: Can you take a thread dump while the cpu is pegged at 100%?

node.contents: I know this doesn't answer your question, but when I run your program using OpenJDK 1.7.0_03 I get around 1% core usage.

node.contents: @Jeffrey Oh, that's interesting. It seems this might be some kind of JVM issue. Probably JohnVint can help to figure this out with the thread dump (looks like chineese to me :)

astNode.text: @Jeffrey Oh, that's interesting. It seems this might be some kind of JVM issue. Probably JohnVint can help to figure this out with the thread dump (looks like chineese to me :)

node.contents: @MostyMostacho Are you sure the thread dump happened before the 10 seconds was up? `pool-1-thread-1` should be in a `TIMED_WAITING` state while it waits for its task, not `RUNNABLE` (at least that's what it's in for me).

astNode.text: @MostyMostacho Are you sure the thread dump happened before the 10 seconds was up? `pool-1-thread-1` should be in a `TIMED_WAITING` state while it waits for its task, not `RUNNABLE` (at least that's what it's in for me).

node.contents: @Jeffrey 100% sure. Note: The only thing I changed from the original code was the delay time (which I set to 600 to give me time enough to get the PID of the process). BTW, I reteseted this and gave me the same result (`pool-1-thread-1` in a `RUNNABLE` state).

astNode.text: @Jeffrey 100% sure. Note: The only thing I changed from the original code was the delay time (which I set to 600 to give me time enough to get the PID of the process). BTW, I reteseted this and gave me the same result (`pool-1-thread-1` in a `RUNNABLE` state).

node.contents: I've got the following simple code:

astNode.text: I've got the following simple code:

elements.contents: package main; import java.util.concurrent.*; public class Main { public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException { new Main(); } public Main() throws InterruptedException { ScheduledExecutorService executor = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(1); executor.schedule(new MyRunnable(), 10, TimeUnit.SECONDS); System.out.println("Shutting down..."); executor.shutdown(); System.out.println("Awaiting termination..."); executor.awaitTermination(Long.MAX_VALUE, TimeUnit.MINUTES); System.out.println("Main finished!"); } private class MyRunnable implements Runnable { public void run() { System.out.println("Finished running!"); } } }

units.rawText: package main; import java.util.concurrent.*; public class Main { public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException { new Main(); } public Main() throws InterruptedException { ScheduledExecutorService executor = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(1); executor.schedule(new MyRunnable(), 10, TimeUnit.SECONDS); System.out.println("Shutting down..."); executor.shutdown(); System.out.println("Awaiting termination..."); executor.awaitTermination(Long.MAX_VALUE, TimeUnit.MINUTES); System.out.println("Main finished!"); } private class MyRunnable implements Runnable { public void run() { System.out.println("Finished running!"); } } }

node.contents: Actually, although my real code is a bit more complex than that, I could isolate the issue in those lines. The code basically waits for 10 seconds to run the runnable and then notifies the ending of the main program.

astNode.text: Actually, although my real code is a bit more complex than that, I could isolate the issue in those lines. The code basically waits for 10 seconds to run the runnable and then notifies the ending of the main program.

node.contents: However, I noticed for a 10 second period, one of my core is used at 100%.

node.contents:
1. Is there something wrong with my code?
  2. Is executor.shutdown(); doing some kind of busy waiting instead of just disabling submission of new tasks?
  3. Or should I blame the JVM?

node.contents: WOW. It's unbelievable it is actually implemented with busy waiting. Looks like my options are updating to Java7 or reimplementing the wheel. The latter seems to be more interesting :) Thanks John!

astNode.text: WOW. It's unbelievable it is actually implemented with busy waiting. Looks like my options are updating to Java7 or reimplementing the wheel. The latter seems to be more interesting :) Thanks John!

node.contents: @MostyMostacho Yea I was a bit too. It seems it delegates to the default implemenation of the TPE which spins like that but wouldn't be busy because there is no schedule concept in a plain thread pool. Nice to see its fixed in Java 7 though

astNode.text: @MostyMostacho Yea I was a bit too. It seems it delegates to the default implemenation of the TPE which spins like that but wouldn't be busy because there is no schedule concept in a plain thread pool. Nice to see its fixed in Java 7 though

node.contents: It is in fact busy waiting. There seems to be no backoff logic for the ThreadPoolExecutor to wait until all tasks are completed (note that this only occurs when you shutdown() otherwise it will suspend the thread correctly).

astNode.text: It is in fact busy waiting. There seems to be no backoff logic for the ThreadPoolExecutor to wait until all tasks are completed (note that this only occurs when you shutdown() otherwise it will suspend the thread correctly).

node.contents: It is continuously checking to see if a task is ready to be executed if it isnt it will try again until the elapsed time has passed for the task to be scheduled.

astNode.text: It is continuously checking to see if a task is ready to be executed if it isnt it will try again until the elapsed time has passed for the task to be scheduled.

node.contents: There is a trade off for shutting down a scheduled thread pool (this trade off is imposed by the implementation). It is to busy spin until the task is ready to schedule or shutdownNow where no queue'd tasks would be executed. However you can then take the list of Runnable's returned and execute them yourself.

astNode.text: There is a trade off for shutting down a scheduled thread pool (this trade off is imposed by the implementation). It is to busy spin until the task is ready to schedule or shutdownNow where no queue'd tasks would be executed. However you can then take the list of Runnable's returned and execute them yourself.

node.contents: @MostyMostacho - Nothing new. Just another example of Oracle trying to "monetize" Java. (But if you need a new emoticon to express yoourself ... try this one ... :-{u )

astNode.text: @MostyMostacho - Nothing new. Just another example of Oracle trying to "monetize" Java. (But if you need a new emoticon to express yoourself ... try this one ... :-{u )

node.contents: There is no emoticon to express my astonishment: "Oracle themselves will be using OpenJDK [as the basis for their own future releases.!](https://blogs.oracle.com/henrik/entry/moving_to_openjdk_as_the)".

astNode.text: There is no emoticon to express my astonishment: "Oracle themselves will be using OpenJDK [as the basis for their own future releases.!](https://blogs.oracle.com/henrik/entry/moving_to_openjdk_as_the)".

node.contents: Hi Stephen, thanks for your input. Indeed this must be some issue with the JVM. However, I'd rather stay with the current VM because I don't want to leave Debian stable repositories (anyway, Java 7 didn't even get to experimental repositories, AFAIK). Thanks again!

astNode.text: Hi Stephen, thanks for your input. Indeed this must be some issue with the JVM. However, I'd rather stay with the current VM because I don't want to leave Debian stable repositories (anyway, Java 7 didn't even get to experimental repositories, AFAIK). Thanks again!

node.contents: This is a platform specific problem. When I ran your test program on my machine, the CPU usage was approximately zero in the 10 second shutdown period ... according to my machine's CPU usage monitoring.

astNode.text: This is a platform specific problem. When I ran your test program on my machine, the CPU usage was approximately zero in the 10 second shutdown period ... according to my machine's CPU usage monitoring.

node.contents: I did a cursory search of the Java bugs database, and nothing relevant showed up.

astNode.text: I did a cursory search of the Java bugs database, and nothing relevant showed up.

node.contents: Looking at the different versions of the source code that you can find on the net (Google), it is clear that the getTask method and friends have had a lot of work done on them between (early) Java 1.6 and (current) Java 1.7.

astNode.text: Looking at the different versions of the source code that you can find on the net (Google), it is clear that the getTask method and friends have had a lot of work done on them between (early) Java 1.6 and (current) Java 1.7.

node.contents: I suggest that you try upgrading your JVM to either the latest Java 1.6 or to Java 1.7. Or at least try this out for your test program. (Or just live with it. This is hardly a show stopper ...)

astNode.text: I suggest that you try upgrading your JVM to either the latest Java 1.6 or to Java 1.7. Or at least try this out for your test program. (Or just live with it. This is hardly a show stopper ...)

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: FYI, this page includes instructions on how to install various versions of Java on Ubuntu.

astNode.text: FYI, this page includes instructions on how to install various versions of Java on Ubuntu.

node.contents:
• One option (for Java 7) is to use the "duinsoft" installer which is a script that pulls the installer from the Oracle site. They've even set up a deb repository to host the installer.

  • Another option is to install the openjdk-7-jdk or openjdk-7-jre packages which are in the 11.10 repos.

astNode.text:
• One option (for Java 7) is to use the "duinsoft" installer which is a script that pulls the installer from the Oracle site. They've even set up a deb repository to host the installer.

  • Another option is to install the openjdk-7-jdk or openjdk-7-jre packages which are in the 11.10 repos.

node.contents: And while you are in the area, don't forget to vote on this RFE to provide the debian package/installer for Java 7.

astNode.text: And while you are in the area, don't forget to vote on this RFE to provide the debian package/installer for Java 7.

node.contents: For the record, this mess is largely a result of Oracle withdrawing licensing for OEM redistibution which mean that the "sun-java-6" package had to be withdrawn. And of course, the "minor problem" that Oracle doesn't provide DEBs.

astNode.text: For the record, this mess is largely a result of Oracle withdrawing licensing for OEM redistibution which mean that the "sun-java-6" package had to be withdrawn. And of course, the "minor problem" that Oracle doesn't provide DEBs.
